flowRoot.flowPara: 282772 Coal and Open-pit surface mining impacts on American Lands (COAL)
Taylor Alexander Brown
Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Oregon State University
<browtayl@oregonstate.edu>
Lewis John McGibbney
NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology
<lewis.mcgibbney@gmail.com>

Figure 0: The San Juan Coal Mine and Generating Station operated by the Westmoreland Coal Company in Waterflow, New Mexico. Courtesy San Juan Citizens Alliance/Ecoflight [?].

Figure 6: The USGS Digital Spectral Library 06 [?] in AVIRIS-C format contains 1365 samples with 225 spectral bands. In this visualization, each column represents a sample and each row represents a band from near-ultraviolet (0.38 µm) above to short-wave infrared (2.5 µm) below. Samples include minerals, vegetation, and synthetic materials.
Figure 8: COAL environmental correlations of mine classifications within 10 m of flowlines in the National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) can be used to identify possible acid mine drainage sites.

Figure 3: A three-dimensional "hypercube" visualization of imaging spectrometer data displaying spectral bands.

Figure 2: (Top left) The Airborne Visible/InfraRed Imaging Spectrometer Classic (AVIRIS-C) and (top right) Next Generation (AVIRIS-NG) instruments are operated by JPL on an aerial platform [?][?]. (Bottom left) The Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) and (bottom right) the Hyperspectral Infrared Imager (HyspIRI) are satellite-mounted instrument missions [?][?].

Figure 5: For each pixel, spectral angle mapper (SAM) classification computes a confidence value for each class in a spectral library (Figure 6) and chooses the one with the maximum value above some threshold. SAM is one of many possible classification algorithms.
Figure 7: Visualization of COAL mineral classifications in the vicinity of the generating station.

Figure 1: (Background) COAL mining classifications, visible-light imagery, and geography of the San Juan Coal Mine. Orange and red pixels were identified as proxy classes for coal mining. Observe their distribution around ponds, reservoirs, streams, and mine facilities. The imagery was from AVIRIS-NG Flight ang20150420t [?] and the geographic data was from The National Map [?].
